head.title: Understanding an Exceptionally Fast and Stable Li-Ion Charging of Highly Fluorinated Graphene with Fine-Controlled C–F Configuration | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Understanding an Exceptionally Fast and Stable Li-Ion Charging of Highly Fluorinated Graphene with Fine-Controlled C–F Configuration

Fluorine (F) atoms with the highest electronegativity and low polarizability can easily modify the surface and composition of carbon-based electrode materials. However, this is accompanied by complete irreversibility and uncontrolled reactivity, thus hindering their use in rechargeable electronic devices. Therefore, understanding the electrochemical effects of the C–F configuration might lead to achieving superior electrochemical properties. Here, we demonstrate that the fluorinated and simultaneously reduced graphene oxide (FrGO) was easily synthesized through direct gas fluorination. The as-prepared 11%-FrGO electrode exhibited a high capacity (1365 mAh g–1 at 0.1 A g–1), remarkable rate capability, and good stability (64% retention after 1000 cycles at 5 A g–1). Furthermore, the annealed FrGO (11%-FrGO(A)) electrode in which the C–F bond configurations were controlled by facile thermal treatment shows long-term stability (80% retention after 1000 cycles at 5 A g–1). Above a certain content, F atoms enhance Li-ion adsorption and electron transfer, accelerate Li-ion diffusion, and facilitate the formation of a solid electrolyte interphase layer. In particular, the C–F configuration plays a significant role in retaining the capacity under harsh recharging conditions. The results in this study could provide valuable insights into the field of rechargeable devices.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Energy scarcity and global warming are serious global threats, and energy storage systems are rapidly evolving to use renewable sources. Owing to their high energy density, good cycling stability, and zero memory effect, lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are being applied in electronic devices, automobiles, and grid energy storage.
(1,2)
However, to satisfy the requirements for next-generation LIBs, electrode materials must be advanced to obtain superior rate capability and high reversible capacity, compared to the current commercial anode material, graphite, which has a low theoretical capacity of 372 mAh g
–1
.
(3,4)

Carbon materials, including graphene, are widely used in LIB electrodes, owing to their low volume expansion, high electrical conductivity, and good chemical stability.
(5−7)
To improve the electrochemical properties of LIBs, graphene can be modified by manipulating its structural, electrical, and chemical properties.
(8,9)
Doping and functionalization with heteroatoms are the most common strategies that effectively alter the carbon structure defects, electronic structures, and interlayer spaces.
(8,10,11)
Fluorine among other heteroatoms such as boron, nitrogen, and sulfur is used for enhancing the performance of batteries due to its highest electronegativity and small polarizability.
(12)
Compared to lithium graphite (Li/C), lithium–fluoride graphite (Li/CF
x
) batteries incorporate fluorine-atom-modified cathodes with a wider operating temperature and higher capacity (865 mAh g
–1
), energy density (1560 Wh kg
–1
), and operating voltage (∼2.4 V vs Li
+
/Li).
(12−14)
However, the irreversibility of the redox reaction ((CF
x
)
n
+
xn
Li →
n
C +
nx
LiF) and explosive reactivity of fluorine atoms have hindered its applications in rechargeable devices.
(15)

Despite these original limitations, fluorine-doped graphene continues to be investigated because the various C–F bonds on them induce extreme differences in electronegativities between fluorine and carbon atoms. Li et al. reported that fluorine-doped reduced graphene oxide (F-rGO) with predominant CF
2
groups was synthesized by the solvothermal process.
(16)
The F-rGO electrode showed a high reversible capacity and excellent cycling stability due to the formation of vacancies in the graphene framework and lowered activation energy in the C–F bond during the doping process. Huang et al. also investigated nitrogen and fluorine co-doped graphene for LIBs.
(17)
They suggested that the semi-ionic and covalent C–F bonds contributed to the enhanced electrochemical performance, resulting from high electrical conductivity and stable SEI layer formation. Nevertheless, these studies do not clarify the effect of fluorine functional groups on electrochemical performance such as outstanding specific capacity, excellent stability, good rate capability, and stable SEI layer.

Although carbon materials can be fluorinated by electrochemical synthesis,
(18)
hydrothermal fluorination,
(19)
direct gas fluorination,
(20−22)
and plasma fluorination,
(23,24)
fluorine-containing carbon-based materials have rarely been studied due to its intractability. The fluorination process also requires harsh conditions, such as high reaction temperatures, long reaction times, and hazardous chemicals.
(21,22,25)
Therefore, it is necessary to study the effect of fluorine on the electrochemical properties of the electrodes and develop a facile synthesis method.

In this work, we simultaneously fluorinated and reduced graphene oxide (FrGO) to achieve a fluorine content of 2–22%, including the reduction of oxygen functional groups. The rGO-based electrode containing 11% fluorine exhibited a capacity of 1365 mAh g
–1
at a current density of 0.1 A g
–1
and 64% retention after 1000 cycles at a current density of 5 A g
–1
. We verified the electrochemical effect of C–F bonds by annealing, and annealed FrGO (11%-FrGO(A)) showed remarkable stability (70% retention) after 3000 cycles at the same current density as unannealed 11%-FrGO. To understand the electrochemical role of fluorine on graphene, structural, chemical, electrical, and electrokinetic analyses of the samples were investigated in this study.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared from graphite (Alfa Aesar, 99.8%) using a modified Hummer’s method.
(26)
Graphite (4 g) was dispersed in sulfuric acid (120 mL, H
2
SO
4
, Deajung Chemicals, 95–98%) by sonication and stirring. Potassium permanganate (15 g, KMnO
4
, Sigma-Aldrich, 99%) was slowly added to the mixture and reacted at 60 °C for 6 h. After cooling for 1 h, deionized water (100 mL) and hydrogen peroxide (10 mL, H
2
O
2
, Deajung Chemicals, 30%) were added to the mixture. To remove the residual acid from the mixture, centrifugation and dialysis were performed. When the pH value of the mixture reached ∼7, GO powder was obtained by freeze drying. GO was fluorinated using the mixture of fluorine gas (F
2
) and nitrogen gas (N
2
). First, GO powder (0.1 g) was placed in a cylindrical reactor. After N
2
purging for 30 min, F
2
/N
2
mixed gases were fed into the reactor at room temperature (RT) until the pressure reached 6 bar. Finally, the residual F
2
was removed by charging with N
2
for 30 min. Fluorination at different mole fractions of F
2
/N
2
(i.e., 1/9, 2/8, 3/7, 4/6, 5/5, and 6/4) was performed, and the corresponding products were denoted as 2%-FrGO, 6%-FrGO, 11%-FrGO, 18%-FrGO, and 22%-FrGO based on X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).

To control the fluorine functional groups, 18%-FrGO was annealed. 18%-FrGO (0.1 g) was loaded in a quartz tube and heated at 200 °C at a heating rate of 5 °C min
–1
in a nitrogen atmosphere for 6 h. After cooling to RT, 11%-FrGO(A) was obtained.

XPS was conducted (Thermo Scientific K-Alpha) with an Al Kα (hv = 1000 eV) source to analyze the molecular bonds on the surface of the samples. The structure was investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Smart Lab) with a Cu Kα source at a scan rate of 5° min
–1
. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Nova NanoSEM 450), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, Tecnai F20), and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) were used to determine the morphology and elemental composition. Thermal decomposition was analyzed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, TA Instruments SDT 2960) in an inert atmosphere at a heating rate of 5 °C min
–1
from 50 to 500 °C. The changes in surface charge were measured using a dynamic light scattering analyzer (Zetasizer Nano-Zs) as a function of the lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF
6
) concentration in diethylene carbonate (DEC) solvent. The sample solutions were prepared by mixing 0.1 mg mL
–1
solutions with 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5 × 10
–3
M LiPF
6
in DEC.

Electrochemical experiments on the GO and FrGO samples were performed using a CR2032-type coin cell. The electrode film was prepared using the doctor blade technique. FrGO (80 wt %) was mixed with Super P (10 wt %, Alfa Aesar) and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVdF, 10 wt %, Sigma-Aldrich) in
N
-methyl-2-pyrrolidone solvent (NMP, Deajung Chemicals, 99.7%), and the resulting slurry was coated on a Cu foil. The coating was dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h, and the obtained electrode film was cut into small disks with 0.5–0.7 mg cm
–2
active material mass. In an argon-filled glovebox with moisture and oxygen levels <1 ppm, the coin cells were assembled with metallic Li foil, Celgard 2400 film, and 1 M LiPF
6
in ethylene carbonate (EC) and DEC (1:1 vol) as the counter electrode, separator, and electrolyte, respectively. The electrode performance was measured by the galvanostatic charge–discharge method in a voltage range between 0.01 and 3 V on the battery test system (Won A Tech WBCS 3000). The
b
-value of the voltammetric response of the electrodes at various sweep rates was determined using the following equation (
eq 1
)
(27,28)
(1)
where
i
is the measured current at a fixed potential with a potential sweep rate and
ν
is the scan rate.

To estimate the Li diffusion coefficient (
D
Li
) of the electrodes, the galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) was performed at a current density of 80 mA g
–1
for 30 min followed by a rest interval of 30 min. The
D
Li
value was calculated using the following equation (
eq 2
)
(29)
(2)
where
D
Li
is the chemical diffusion coefficient of Li ions (cm
2
s
–1
), τ is the duration of the current pulse (s),
m
b
is the mass of the active material (g),
V
m
is the molar volume of the active material (cm
3
mol
–1
),
M
B
is the molar mass of the active material (g mol
–1
),
S
is the surface area of the electrode (cm
2
), Δ
E
s
is the steady-state voltage change, and Δ
E
t
is the voltage change during the constant current pulse. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and cyclic voltammetry (CV) were performed using an electrochemical potentiostat (Autolab PGSTAT302/NAutolab FRA 2). EIS was measured at a frequency of 0.1–10 kHz with an AC amplitude of 5 mV. The CV curve was obtained at a scan rate of 0.5 mV s
–1
. Further CV analysis was performed to investigate the kinetics at scan rates of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 mV s
–1
.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Although F
2
gas has high reactivity with other materials owing to its low dissociation energy (155 kJ mol
–1
) and high electronegativity, fluorination of graphitic materials has rarely been conducted.
(30)
GO has been widely studied as a basic unit that can be modified to provide highly functional carbonaceous materials.
(31)
We used GO, obtained by the oxidation of graphite using the modified Hummer’s method, as a raw material in this study because it contains various structural and chemical defects that could feasibly be substituted. We speculated that with its numerous oxygen functional groups, GO would be a good base material for synthesizing FrGO with a high fluorine content because C–F bonds are preferentially formed by substitution of hydroxyl and epoxy groups on the GO plane at low temperatures during fluorination.
(32−34)
As previously reported, fluorine dopants are ionized, decomposed, and dissociated by chemical,
(35)
hydrothermal,
(19)
and plasma treatment,
(36)
respectively, and the resulting products contain fluorinated carbon. However, below ∼8 atom %, the fluorine content was unsatisfactory. Therefore, we chose direct gas fluorination as a fast and practical method to obtain high fluorine content, in which covalent, semi-ionic, and other types of C–F bonds were realized (
Figure 1
a).

div.p: Figure 1. (a) Schematic illustration of the FrGO synthesis through direct gas fluorination. (b) Atomic ratios of FrGO samples from XPS analysis. (c) XPS C 1s spectra of GO and FrGO samples. (d) XRD diffractograms of GO and FrGO samples.

div.div:
XPS analysis was conducted to verify the fluorination and characterize the fluorine bond configurations of the samples.
Figure 1
b shows the atomic ratios of carbon, oxygen, and fluorine for the GO and FrGO samples. The atomic ratio of fluorine represents the sum of semi-ionic and covalent C–F bonds by deconvoluted F 1s spectra of the samples (
Figure S1b
). As the mole fraction of F
2
in the mixed gases increased, a decrease in the oxygen content coupled with an increase in the fluorine content was clearly observed. As shown in
Figure 1
c, the intensity of the C–O bond gradually decreased up to 11% fluorine atoms on the rGO, which corresponds to the O 1s spectra (
Figure S1a
). Moreover, semi-ionic C–F, covalent C–F, CF
2
, and CF
3
bonds were found at 288.4, 289.6, 290.9, and 292.3 eV, respectively.
(37−39)
When the fluorination process was carried out, the temperature inside the reactor increased due to exothermic heat. Therefore, we suspect that the reduction of GO occurs as a result of two factors: (1) unstable C–O bonds react with fluorine radicals
(33)
and (2) the enthalpy of forming C–F bonds (−495 kJ mol
–1
) presents enough thermal energy to remove oxygen functional groups on GO (∼167 kJ mol
–1
) by the exothermic reaction.
(40,41)
However, 18%-FrGO and 22%-FrGO, which were fluorinated at high fluorine concentrations, exhibited considerable variation in carbon and fluorine contents. Interestingly, the semi-ionic C–F bond continuously increased with the saturation of the covalent C–F bond when mixed gases with high fluorine concentrations were injected (
Figure 1
b). This implies that excessive F
2
gas resulted in an increase in the semi-ionic C–F bond and disturbed or collapsed hexagonal structure due to carbon etching. This phenomenon was confirmed by structural analysis, as shown in
Figure 1
d. The (001) plane of GO was observed at ∼11° due to the presence of oxygen functional groups between the interlayers.
(42)
As the degree of fluorination continued to increase, similar to the chemical or thermal reduction of GO, the (001) plane progressively disappeared and the (002) plane shifted to a higher angle up to 11%-FrGO. However, the diffraction intensity of the (002) plane continuously decreased with increasing fluorination and was also shifted to a lower angle beyond 11% fluorination. This indicates that carbon etching of graphene occurred via excessive fluorination, which is in agreement with the XPS results. Moreover, the ratio of the intensity of D and G peak (
I
D
/
I
G
ratio) gradually increased after high-level fluorination in Raman spectra (
Figure S2 and Table S1
). Hence, it was hypothesized that the introduction of fluorine atoms into graphene would alter the electronic structure but the intrinsic crystalline nature of graphene was maintained with the incorporation of up to 11% fluorine atoms.

We also verified the morphologies of GO and 11%-FrGO using SEM and TEM, as shown in
Figure 2
. In contrast to the smooth and flat surface of GO (
Figure 2
a), 11%-FrGO exhibited a corrugated and crumpled morphology (
Figure 2
b). The FrGOs with higher fluorine content were more wrinkled and exfoliated to maintain thermodynamically stable bending during the fluorination process (
Figure S3
).
(43)
To investigate the distribution of fluorine in the 11%-FrGO, we performed STEM elemental mapping of carbon and fluorine, as shown in
Figure 2
c,d, respectively. The inset in
Figure 2
c shows a TEM micrograph of the same area. We confirmed that fluorine was uniformly distributed at the edge and in the basal plane on graphene, indicating that fluorine atoms were effectively introduced into the graphene framework during direct gas fluorination.

div.p: Figure 2. SEM images of (a) GO and (b) 11%-FrGO. STEM elemental mapping of (c) carbon (gray) and (d) fluorine (yellow) for 11%-FrGO corresponding to the rectangular area in the inset.

div.div:
We tested the electrochemical performance of the GO and FrGO samples using the galvanostatic method.
Figure 3
a shows rate capabilities of GO and FrGO electrodes at various current densities from 0.1 to 5 A g
–1
. The values increased for samples containing up to 11% fluorine; however, a higher content led to a low rate capability. The 11%-FrGO electrode exhibited not only the best rate capability but also the highest capacity. This electrode achieved capacities of 1365, 1131, 851, 661, 519, and even 343 mAh g
–1
at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 A g
–1
, respectively. It is expected that there is an optimal fluorine content to enhance the electrochemical performance, which arises from excessive fluorination to render the disturbance or collapse of the graphene structure by carbon etching, leading to the extinction of Li-ion storage sites and low electrical conductivity. When the current density returned to 0.1 A g
–1
, the discharge capacity of 11%-FrGO was restored to its initial capacity after several cycles. Moreover, the capacities of all electrodes were stable despite the change in current densities, indicating that the sp
2
-hybridized primary structure of carbon was better preserved without volume expansion during lithiation–delithiation processes than for the other conversions and alloy materials, such as those based on SiO
2
(
Figure S4
). Although analogous redox reactions of GO and FrGO electrodes were observed (
Figure S5
), the difference in capacity clearly depends on the degree of fluorination, except for the first cycle. We investigated the redox kinetics, electronic transport, and electrophoresis using CV and ζ-potentials to verify the electrochemical performance in terms of the degree of fluorination.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) Rate capability of GO and FrGO electrodes at current densities of 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 A g
–1
. (b) Calculated
b
-values of GO and FrGO electrodes at a voltage range of 0.1–1 V. (c) GITT curves of GO and 11%-FrGO at the second cycle. (d) Li-ion diffusion coefficient of GO and FrGO electrodes during the lithiation process. (e) ζ-Potential of GO and FrGO samples as a function of LiPF
6
concentration in DEC solvent at 20 °C. (f) Nyquist plots of GO and FrGO electrodes after the rate capability test using the equivalent circuit model (inset).

div.div:
We carried out CV tests to examine the redox kinetics of the electrode reaction at different scan rates (
Figure S6
). In the charge–discharge profiles of the electrodes (
Figure S7
), the capacities of all electrodes were below 1 V during the lithiation process. Thus, the
b
-values of electrodes were calculated in terms of voltage range from 1.0 to 0.1 V. Generally, the kinetics can be determined by calculating the
b
-values, which are classified as the diffusion-controlled contribution (
b
≈ 0.5, battery electrode material) and capacitive contribution (
b
≈ 1, capacitor electrode material).
(28,44)
As shown in
Figure 3
b, the
b
-values approached 0.5–0.6, when the voltage was close to 0.1 V, indicating that the Li-ion insertion process occurred in the graphene (i.e., diffusion-controlled contribution). Another interesting finding is that the b-value grows steadily as the fluorine content increases in the voltage range of 0.1–0.5. We suggest that in the electrochemical system for which
b
> 0.5, the reaction is less limited by ion diffusion due to the fast redox reaction.
(45)
Electrodes with a fluorine content of >6 atom % show a tendency to increase
b
-value at voltages of over 0.5 V, indicating that their charge storage behavior is attributed to capacitive contribution. This result is in good agreement with the CV results, which verifies the increasing capacitances after fluorination (
Figure S5
). Considering that Li ions are locally adsorbed onto the surface of FrGO, an electric charging layer to induce changes in the electrochemical morphology could be generated around the fluorine atom by Coulombic force. Therefore, we suggest that the enormous capacity of FrGO originated from the additional Li-ion adsorption on the interface of FrGO, in addition to the insertion of Li ions into the plane, defects, and edge sites of rGO.

To further understand the kinetics and transport properties, we conducted a GITT test.
Figure 3
c shows the GITT curves of GO and 11%-FrGO at the second cycle with a current density of 80 mA g
–1
for a duration of 30 min and rest interval of 30 min. The 11%-FrGO electrode exhibited a lower overpotential than the GO electrode; this difference was distinct at high voltage ranges from 1.0 to 3.0 V. From this observation, it can be inferred that fluorine affects the density of electronic states near the Fermi level by strong interaction of carbon and fluorine atoms, leading to enhanced heterogeneous electron transfer.
(46)
The calculated
D
Li
values for the GO and FrGO electrodes are shown in
Figure 3
d. We observed that the
D
Li
of the electrodes tended to increase as the content of C–F bonds increased. Interestingly, the
D
Li
value of 11%-FrGO is ∼4.4 times higher than that of GO in all voltage ranges. For additional evidence for enhancement Li-ion diffusion and adsorption in the presence of fluorine atoms, we measured the ζ-potentials using various LiPF
6
concentrations from 0.01 to 0.05 mM in DEC solvent at 20 °C, as shown in
Figure 3
e.
(47)
The ζ-potentials of GO and 2%-FrGO showed no significant change with increasing LiPF
6
concentration. Although the ζ-potential of 6%-FrGO changed slightly, those of 11-, 18-, and 22%-FrGO significantly changed from negative to positive at concentrations of 0–2 × 10
–3
M LiPF
6
. This result suggests that fluorine atoms cause fast Li-ion diffusion when the Li-ion concentration gradient is frequently, suddenly, and locally generated at the interface between the electrode and electrolyte during lithiation at a low voltage range, thus readily attracting lithium cations by electrical force.
(48)
In addition, considering the wrinkled morphology and hydrophobic properties of FrGO compared to GO (
Figure 2
), the enhanced wettability of FrGO also affects the outstanding rate of Li-ion diffusion in the main voltage range of the electrochemical reaction.

The electrochemical performance results correspond with the EIS analysis, as shown in
Figure 3
f. The resistance parameters, based on the equivalent circuit (inset of
Figure 3
f), are listed in
Table S2
. The Nyquist plots of all electrodes were obtained as semicircles in the high-frequency region due to the SEI layer resistance (
R
SEI
) and charge-transfer resistance (
R
ct
). In particular, the
R
ct
value of the 11%-FrGO electrode was lower than those of the other electrodes, which was attributed to the appropriate functionalization of graphene with minimal structural damage as well as the formation of C–F bonds. Moreover, in the low-frequency region, the slope of the 11%-FrGO electrode was steeper than those of GO, 3%-FrGO, and 6%-FrGO, which resulted from fast Li-ion diffusion.

To further understand the effect of the C–F configuration on the electrochemical characteristics, we prepared FrGO samples each containing 11% fluorine and different configuration ratios of semi-ionic and covalent C–F bonds by facile heat treatment, based on the electrochemical performance of FrGO. Before the treatment, the thermal behavior of GO and FrGO was first determined by TGA. The decomposition of oxygen functional groups on GO occurred at ca. 180–220 °C (
Figure S8
). In the TGA thermogram of 18%-FrGO, as shown in
Figure 4
a, barely any weight loss occurred below 220 °C. This phenomenon was expected because of the decomposition of the relatively weak semi-ionic C–F bond above 220 °C and the subsequent removal of the covalent C–F bond. Based on these results, we synthesized 11%-FrGO(A), which had an equal atomic ratio of 11%-FrGO with different fluorine functional groups, using the 18%-FrGO sample described in
Section 2
. After obtaining 11%-FrGO(A) by thermal annealing at 200 °C for 6 h, we measured the C/O/F atomic ratio as 74.6:13.3:12.1, similar to that of 11%-FrGO without annealing (75.1:13.5:11.4). Interestingly, the variation in the C–F configuration was evident, as shown in
Figure 4
b. The intensity of the covalent C–F bond for 11%-FrGO(A) at 689.8 eV increased in comparison with those of 11%-FrGO and 18%-FrGO, indicating a decrease in semi-ionic C–F bonds by annealing. The area ratio of covalent C–F for 11%-FrGO(A) was ∼3.6 times larger than that of 11%-FrGO (
Figure S9
). Although the intensity and area of the covalent C–F bond in 11%-FrGO(A) were different from those of 11%-FrGO, there was no distinction in the electrochemical performance (
Figures S10–S12
). However, the differences in cycling stability were significant after 1000 cycles at a current density of 5 A g
–1
, as shown in
Figure 4
c. The 11%-FrGO(A) electrode shows a stable performance for 3000 cycles, whereas the capacity of 11%-FrGO begins to decline after 1000 cycles.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) TGA thermogram of 18%-FrGO under nitrogen atmosphere. (b) XPS F 1s spectra of 11%-FrGO, 18%-FrGO, and 11%-FrGO(A). (c) Cycling stability of 11%-FrGO and 11%-FrGO(A) electrodes for 3000 cycles at a current density of 5 A g
–1
.

div.div:
The redox reactions of 11%-FrGO and 11%-FrGO(A) electrodes in the first cycle were investigated to determine the key factors that enhanced the cycling stability of the 11%-FrGO(A) electrode. The CV curves of the redox reactions with samples containing different C–F configurations are plotted in
Figure 5
a. We observed that the voltage required to form the SEI layer increased with an increase in the amount of covalent C–F bonds. This voltage shift is closely related to the characteristics of the Li-ion interface kinetics during the cathodic reaction.
(49,50)
According to a study by Moradabadi et al., the decomposition of the electrolyte is related to the surface chemical composition and surface potential of the electrode,
(51)
which is covered by the SEI layer, and the formation of the SEI layer is affected by the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) and highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO).
(49)
It is interesting to note that the introduction of a fluorine atom in graphene causes a change in the LUMO energy level.
(33)
We can therefore infer that the covalent C–F bond assists in providing rapid and short cathodic reactions for the formation of the SEI layer, resulting from the small interface polarization.

div.p: Figure 5. (a) CV curves of 11%-FrGO and 11%-FrGO(A) at the first cycle. (b) F 1s spectra of 11%-FrGO and 11%-FrGO(A) before cycling, after three cycles, and after 3000 cycles. SEM images of the top section of (c) 11%-FrGO and (d) 11%-FrGO(A) electrode after 3000 cycles (inset: electrodes after three cycles).

div.div:
The XPS spectra given in
Figure 5
b show the SEI layer on 11%-FrGO(A). In the F 1s spectra of the 11%-FrGO and 11%-FrGO(A) electrodes before cycling, the identical peaks of the two electrodes at 687.8 eV originate from the binder (PVdF) and fluorine functional group on graphene. After three cycles, a new peak of the two electrodes occurs at 685 eV, which corresponds to LiF due to the formation of an SEI layer during the initial cycles. However, after 3000 cycles, the intensity of the LiF peak for the 11%-FrGO electrode is higher than that of the 11%-FrGO electrode(A). The morphologies of the electrodes on the change of the SEI layer are also differentiated depending on the C–F configuration. After three cycles, the morphology of the 11%-FrGO electrode is similar to that of 11%-FrGO(A) (insets in
Figure 5
c,d), compared to that before cycling (
Figure S13
). However, the 11%-FrGO electrode was covered with a thick SEI layer on the surface, as shown in
Figure 5
c. Despite long-term cycling at a high current density of 5 A g
–1
, 11%-FrGO(A) had a smooth and thin SEI layer (
Figure 5
d). The 11%-FrGO possesses a higher semi-ionic C–F bond than 11%-FrGO(A), as shown in the XPS spectra in
Figure 4
b, indicating that the semi-ionic C–F bond contributes to the formation of the SEI layer, owing to its relatively weak bond strength. Therefore, we believe that the high fluorine content and configuration of FrGO can be attributed to the capacity (due to electronic, structural, and morphological changes) and stability (due to the formation of a thin SEI layer), respectively.

Based on the overall results, we have explained the effect of C–F configurations on the electrochemical performance and formation mechanism of the SEI layer during the charge–discharge process (
Figure 6
a). First, in the charge–discharge process, fluorine atoms play a role in the additional Li-ion adsorption on the surface of FrGO and the formation of an electric charging layer, leading to a 3-fold higher capacity of FrGO than that of pristine GO. Second, fluorine atoms can provide heterogeneous electron transfer and fast Li-ion diffusion by tuning the electronic states and morphologies of graphene. It should be noted that the capacity of FrGO (1365 mAh g
–1
at 0.1 A g
–1
) is much higher than that of commercially available graphite (372 mAh g
–1
at 0.037 A g
–1
). Furthermore, FrGO exhibited a rate capability of 519 mAh g
–1
at a current density of 2 A g
–1
, which is 18 times higher than that of graphite, although the graphite-based anode operates at a current density of only 1.1 A g
–1
. Finally, it is clarified that the covalent C–F bond, which is stronger than the semi-ionic C–F bond, gives a stable and thin SEI layer, which significantly improves the long-term stability of the electrodes. The retention of 11%-FrGO(A) was 80 and 70% after 1000 and 3000 cycles, respectively, when FrGO was used as an anode. Therefore, we can confirm that one-step fluorination and modulation of the C–F bonding configuration overcome three current challenging issues in LIBs: capacity, fast charging rate, and even stability. Despite enormous efforts to develop a new anode to satisfy the US Department of Energy’s targets, which includes performances higher than 1000 mAh g
–1
and 1000 cycles, carbon-based materials in the open literature have proven sufficient (
Figure 6
b and
Table S3
). Our novel approach using simply modified materials in the anode is practical and leads to high-performing LIBs.

div.p: Figure 6. (a) Schematic illustration of the effect of fluorine functional groups on electrochemical performance. (b) Comparison of the retention capacities of advanced anode materials in LIBs under fast charging condition.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In summary, we easily synthesized FrGOs with varying fluorine content through direct gas fluorination using GO at different mole fractions of mixed F
2
/N
2
gases. During the fluorination process, various types of C–F bonds were effectively introduced onto the graphene framework, including the simultaneous reduction of oxygen functional groups. When FrGOs were utilized as the electrode material for LIBs, FrGOs with fluorine content above a certain value facilitated numerous Li-ion adsorption, accelerated Li-ion diffusion, and enhanced electron transfer. For this reason, the 11%-FrGO electrode demonstrated the best electrochemical performance, with superior capacity (1365 mAh g
–1
at a current density of 0.1 A g
–1
) and good stability (64% retention after 1000 cycles at a current density of 5 A g
–1
). To further understand the electrochemical effect of the C–F configurations, 11%-FrGO(A), possessing a covalent-rich C–F bond, was prepared by supplementary heat treatment. As a result, the 11%-FrGO(A) electrode showed better stability after 3000 cycles (70% retention) than the 11%-FrGO electrode (6% retention) without compromising the performance. This can be attributed to the formation of a stable, thin SEI layer due to the strong, covalent C–F bonds. Given this excellent performance, we believe that the FrGO anode reported herein has significant potential for use in long-life, next-generation LIBs.

A review. Li-ion battery technol. has become very important in recent years as these batteries show great promise as power sources that can lead us to the elec. vehicle (EV) revolution. The development of new materials for Li-ion batteries is the focus of research in prominent groups in the field of materials science throughout the world. Li-ion batteries can be considered to be the most impressive success story of modern electrochem. in the last two decades. They power most of today's portable devices, and seem to overcome the psychol. barriers against the use of such high energy d. devices on a larger scale for more demanding applications, such as EV. Since this field is advancing rapidly and attracting an increasing no. of researchers, it is important to provide current and timely updates of this constantly changing technol. In this review, we describe the key aspects of Li-ion batteries: the basic science behind their operation, the most relevant components, anodes, cathodes, electrolyte solns., as well as important future directions for R&D of advanced Li-ion batteries for demanding use, such as EV and load-leveling applications.

The storage of elec. energy at high charge and discharge rate is an important technol. in today's society, and can enable hybrid and plug-in hybrid elec. vehicles and provide back-up for wind and solar energy. It is typically believed that in electrochem. systems very high power rates can only be achieved with supercapacitors, which trade high power for low energy d. as they only store energy by surface adsorption reactions of charged species on an electrode material. Batteries which obtain high energy d. by storing charge in the bulk of a material can also achieve ultrahigh discharge rates, comparable to those of supercapacitors. The authors realize this in LiFePO4 (ref. 6), a material with high lithium bulk mobility, by creating a fast ion-conducting surface phase through controlled off-stoichiometry. A rate capability equiv. to full battery discharge in 10-20 s can be achieved.

The recent development of lithium rechargeable batteries results from the use of carbon materials as lithium reservoir at the neg. electrode. Reversible intercalation, or insertion, of lithium into the carbon host lattice avoids the problem of lithium dendrite formation and provides large improvement in terms of cycleability and safety. This paper reviews, with 149 refs., the main achievements on performance and understanding of charge-discharge mechanisms, resulting from the tremendous activity devoted to these systems in the past few years. As a matter of fact. all carbon materials can be lithiated to a certain extent. However, the amt. of lithium reversibly incorporated in the carbon lattice (the reversible capacity), the faradaic losses during the first charge-discharge cycle (the irreversible capacity), the profile of the voltage curves during charging and discharging, all depend on the structure, the texture and heteroatom content of the carbon material. We successively examine the electrochem. behavior of the main families of materials, namely, natural and synthetic graphites, graphitizable carbons, low-temp. and non-graphitizing carbons, and doped carbons.

2D materials. Graphene, related two-dimensional crystals, and hybrid systems for energy conversion and storage
Bonaccorso Francesco; Colombo Luigi; Yu Guihua; Stoller Meryl; Tozzini Valentina; Ferrari Andrea C; Ruoff Rodney S; Pellegrini Vittorio
Science (New York, N.Y.)

Graphene and related two-dimensional crystals and hybrid systems showcase several key properties that can address emerging energy needs, in particular for the ever growing market of portable and wearable energy conversion and storage devices. Graphene's flexibility, large surface area, and chemical stability, combined with its excellent electrical and thermal conductivity, make it promising as a catalyst in fuel and dye-sensitized solar cells. Chemically functionalized graphene can also improve storage and diffusion of ionic species and electric charge in batteries and supercapacitors. Two-dimensional crystals provide optoelectronic and photocatalytic properties complementing those of graphene, enabling the realization of ultrathin-film photovoltaic devices or systems for hydrogen production. Here, we review the use of graphene and related materials for energy conversion and storage, outlining the roadmap for future applications.

A review. The ever-increasing demands for energy and environmental concerns due to burning fossil fuels are the key drivers of today's R&D of innovative energy storage systems. This paper provides an overview of recent research progress in graphene-based materials as electrodes for electrochem. energy storage. Beginning with a brief description of the important properties of single-layer graphene, methods for the prepn. of graphene and its derivs. (graphene oxide and reduced graphene oxide) are summarized. Then, graphene-based electrode materials for electrochem. capacitors and lithium-ion batteries are reviewed. The use of graphene for improving the performance of lithium-sulfur and lithium-oxygen batteries is also presented. Future research trend in the development of high-power-d. and high-energy-d. electrochem. energy storage devices is analyzed.

The preparation of porous graphite and its application in lithium ion batteries as anode material
Deng, Tianshu; Zhou, Xiaoping

Graphite is the most widely used anode material for lithium ion batteries (LIBs). However, the performance of graphite is limited by its slow charging rates. In this work, porous graphite was successfully prepd. by nickel-catalyzed gasification. The existence of the pores and channels in graphite particles can greatly increase the no. of sites for Li-ion intercalation-deintercalation in graphite lattice and reduce the Li-ion diffusion distance, which can greatly facilitate the rapid diffusion of lithium ions; meanwhile, the pores and channels can act as buffers for the vol. change of the graphite in charging-discharging processes. As a result, the prepd. graphite with pores and channels exhibits excellent cycling stability at high rate as anode materials for LIBs. The porous graphite offers better cycling performance than pristine graphite, retaining 81.4 % of its initial reversible capacity after 1500 cycles at 5 C rates. The effective synthesis strategy might open new avenues for the design of high-performance graphite materials. The porous graphite anode material is proposed in applications of high rate charging Li-ion batteries for elec. vehicles.

A challenge in the development of Li ion batteries is to simultaneously achieve high power and large energy capacity at fast charge and discharge rates for several minutes to seconds. N- or B-doped graphene can be used as a promising anode for high-power and high-energy Li ion batteries under high-rate charge and discharge conditions. The doped graphene shows a high reversible capacity of >1040 mA-h/g at a low rate of 50 mA/g. More importantly, it can be quickly charged and discharged in a short time of 1 h to several tens of seconds together with high-rate capability and excellent long-term cyclability. For example, a high capacity of ∼199 and 235 mA-h/g was obtained for the N-doped graphene and B-doped graphene at 25 A/g (∼30 s to full charge). Probably the unique 2-dimensional structure, disordered surface morphol., heteroat. defects, better electrode/electrolyte wettability, increased inter-sheet distance, improved elec. cond., and thermal stability of the doped graphene are beneficial to rapid surface Li+ absorption and ultrafast Li+ diffusion and electron transport. The doped materials are accordingly superior to pristine chem. derived graphene and other carbonaceous materials.

Wang, Huanjing; Sun, Xiuxia; Liu, Zonghuai; Lei, Zhibin

Creation of nanopores on graphene planar sheets is of great significance in promoting the kinetic diffusion of electrolyte and enhancing the utilization efficiency of graphene planar sheets. Herein, we developed a facile chem. vapor deposition strategy to prep. highly porous graphene with flake-like MgO as template and ferrocene as the carbon precursor. The graphene layers show a highly porous structure with small mesopores of 4-8 nm, large mesopores of 10-20 nm and addnl. macropores of 100-200 nm. These nanopores on graphene sheets provide numerous channels for fast ion transport perpendicular to the 2D basal plane, while the good powder cond. ensures an effective electron propagation within the 2D graphene plane. As a result, a specific capacitance of 303 F g-1, an areal capacitance up to 17.3 μF cm-2 and a nearly tenfold shorter time const. were achieved when compared with those of nonporous and stacked graphene electrodes. The method demonstrated herein would open up an opportunity to prep. porous graphene for a wide applications in energy storage, biosensors, nanoelectronics and catalysis.

; ISSN:
1754-5706
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
A review. Heteroatom doped carbon materials represent one of the most prominent families of materials that are used in energy related applications, such as fuel cells, batteries, hydrogen storage or supercapacitors. While doping carbons with nitrogen atoms has experienced great progress throughout the past decades and yielded promising material concepts, also other doping candidates have gained the researchers' interest in the last few years. Boron is already relatively widely studied, and as its electronic situation is contrary to the one of nitrogen, codoping carbons with both heteroatoms can probably create synergistic effects. Sulfur and phosphorus have just recently entered the world of carbon synthesis, but already the first studies published prove their potential, esp. as electrocatalysts in the cathodic compartment of fuel cells. Due to their size and their electronegativity being lower than those of carbon, structural distortions and changes of the charge densities are induced in the carbon materials. This article is to give a state of the art update on the most recent developments concerning the advanced heteroatom doping of carbon that goes beyond nitrogen. Doped carbon materials and their applications in energy devices are discussed with respect to their boron-, sulfur- and phosphorus-doping.

The application of Li ion battery (LIB) in portable electronics and elec. vehicle has received tremendous attention, however, challenges remain in seeking suitable high-capacity anode materials with excellent rate performance and thus potentially to boost the energy/power d. Here the authors report an arc-discharge prodn. of high-quality F-modified graphene as anode for LIB with high-rate capability. As a result of F-modified, the acquired graphene exhibits high at. ratio of C/O, excellent elec. cond. and more crumpled and wrinkled surface. The in-situ formation of LiF nanoparticles during the 1st Li+ insertion process not only act as barriers to effectively prevent the agglomeration and re-stacking of graphene sheets but also enhance the interlayer spacing, thus providing enough void for rapid Li+ ion insertion/extn. These optimized features enable the resultant F-modified graphene delivers a high reversible capacity (783.2 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1), outstanding rate performance (298.5 mAh g-1 at 10 A g-1), and excellent cycling stability (> 91% capacity retention after 1000 cycles), providing great application prospect in high-energy-power LIB.

N and F co-doped graphene (NFG) with the N and F content ≤3.24 and 10.9 at.% resp. was prepd. through the hydrothermal reaction of triethylamine tri(hydrofluoride) [Et3N·3HF] and aq.-dispersed graphene oxide (GO) as the anode material for Li ion batteries (LIBs). The N and F co-doping in graphene increased the disorder and defects of the framework, enlarged the space of the interlayer, wrinkled the nanosheets with many open-edge sites, and thus facilitated Li ion diffusion through the electrode compared with sole-N or F doped graphene. XPS anal. of NFG demonstrated the presence of active pyridine and pyrrolic type N, and highly elec. conductive graphitic N and the semi-ionic C-F bond in the structure. The N and F doping content and the component types of N and F functional groups could be controlled by the hydrothermal temp. The NFG prepd. at 150° exhibited the best electrochem. performances when tested as the anode for LIBs, including the high coulombic efficiency in the 1st cycle (56.7%), superior reversible specific discharge capacity (1075 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1), excellent rate capabilities (305 mA h g-1 at 5 A g-1), and outstanding cycling stability (capacity retention of ∼95% at 5 A g-1 after 2000 cycles), which demonstrated that NFG was a promising candidate for anode materials of high-rate LIBs.

Covalent bond-forming reactions can be used to tailor the properties of graphene, aiming at electronic band structure engineering and surface functionalization. We present a novel and easy method for the prodn. of chem. modified monolayer graphene based on the electrochem. intercalation of graphite, that could be used for adding various functional groups to the graphene lattice. Oxy-fluorinated graphene layers have been produced and fully characterized in terms of their chem. compn. and functionalization. Moreover, Raman spectroscopy allows ready discrimination between monolayers and few-layers, and field-effect devices were fabricated to study the transport properties of monolayer graphene oxyfluoride. We report the synthesis and evidence of graphene fluoride, a 2D wide bandgap semiconductor derived from graphene. Graphene fluoride exhibits hexagonal cryst. order and strongly insulating behavior with resistance exceeding 10 GΩ at room temp. Electron transport in graphene fluoride is well described by variable range hopping in 2 dimensions due to the presence of localized states in the band gap. Graphene obtained through the redn. of graphene fluoride is highly conductive, exhibiting a resistivity of <100 kΩ at room temp. Our approach provides a pathway to reversibly engineer the band structure and cond. of graphene for electronic and optical applications.

Since the advent of graphene, there was intense interest in exploring the possibility of incorporating fluorinated graphene (FG), an ultrathin insulator, into graphene electronics as barriers, gate dielecs., and optoelectronic elements. Here the authors report on the synthesis of FG from single-layer graphene sheets grown by chem. vapor deposition (CVD) using CF4 plasma. The authors examine its properties systematically via microscopic and spectroscopic probes. The authors' studies show that, by controlling the conditions of the plasma, FG of varying fluorine coverage can be produced; however, the resulting material contains a mixt. of CFx (x = 1-3) bonds. Existing grain boundaries and lattice defects of CVD graphene play an important role in controlling its rate of fluorination and the damage of the sheet. Combining topog. and current mapping, the spatial distribution of fluorine on CVD graphene is highly inhomogeneous, where multilayer islands and structural features such as folds, wrinkles, and ripples are less fluorinated and consequently form a conductive network through which charge transport occurs. It is the properties of this network that manifest in the elec. transport of FG sheets. The authors' expts. reveal the many challenges of deriving electronics-quality FG from current CVD graphene while at the same time point to the possible solns. and potential of FG in graphene electronics and optoelectronics.

Amorphous molybdenum sulfide (MoSx) is covalently anchored to reduced graphene oxide (r-GO) via a simple one-pot reaction, thereby inducing the redn. of GO and simultaneous doping of heteroatoms on the GO. The oxygen atoms form a bridged between MoSx and GO and play a crucial role in the fine dispersion of the MoSx particles, control of planar MoSx growth, and increase of exposed active sulfur sites. This bridging leads to highly efficient (-157 mV overpotential and 41 mV/decade Tafel slope) and stable (95% vs. initial activity after 1000 cycles) electrocatalyst for hydrogen evolution.

The advantages of using nanostructured materials for electrochem. energy storage have focused on the benefits assocd. with short path lengths. However, another contribution, capacitive effects which become increasingly important at nanoscale dimensions, was studied. Nanocryst. TiO2 (anatase) was studied over a dimensional regime where both capacitive and Li intercalation processes contribute to the total stored charge. An anal. of the voltammetric sweep data was used to distinguish between the amt. of charge stored by these 2 processes. At particle sizes <10 nm, capacitive contributions became increasingly important, leading to greater amts. of total stored charge (gravimetrically normalized) with decreasing TiO2 particle size. The area normalized capacitance is well >100 μF/cm2, confirming that the capacitive contribution was pseudocapacitive. Also, decreasing the particle size to the nanoscale regime led to faster charge/discharge rates because diffusion-controlled Li ion intercalation was replaced by faradaic reactions which occur at the surface of the material. The charge storage and kinetic benefits derived from using nanoscale metal oxides provide an interesting direction for the design of materials that offer both power d. and energy d.

An electrochem. galvanostatic intermittent titrn. technique is described which combines both transient and steady-state measurements to obtain kinetic properties of solid mixed-conducting electrodes, as well as thermodn. data. The derivation of quantities such as the chem. and component diffusion coeffs., the partial cond., the mobility, the thermodn. enhancement factor, and the parabolic rate const. as a function of stoichiometry is presented. A description of the factors governing the equil. of compn. gradients in such phases is included. The technique is applied to the detn. of the kinetic parameters of Li3Sb, which has a narrow compn. range. For Li2.9994Sb the chem. diffusion coeff. is 2 × 10-5 cm2-s-1 at 360°. This value is quite high, due to a large thermodn. enhancement factor of 1.3 × 104. The Li component diffusion coeff. at this compn. is 1.5 × 10-9 cm2-s3-1. The partial conductivity and elec. mobility of Li are 1.5 × 10-4 Ω-1-cm-1 and 3 × 10-8 cm2-V-1-s-1, resp., at the same stoichiometry and temp. Because of the very large values of the chem. diffusion coeff. and the fact that 3 mols of Li can react per mol of Sb, this system may be of interest for use in new types of secondary batteries.

A direct gas-solid reaction between fluorine gas (F2) and graphene is expected to become an inexpensive, continuous and scalable prodn. method to prep. fluorinated graphene. However, the dependence of the fluorination intercalation of graphene is still poorly understood, which prevents the formation of high-quality fluorinated graphene. Herein, we demonstrate that chem. defects (oxygen group defects) on graphene sheets play a leading role in promoting fluorination intercalation, whereas phys. defects (point defects), widely considered to be an advantage due to more diffusion channels for F2, were not influential. Based on the above investigations, we successfully prepd. fluorinated graphene with an ultrahigh interlayer distance (9.7 Å), the largest value reported for fluorinated graphene, by customizing graphene with more hydroxyl and epoxy groups. It presented excellent self-lubricating ability, with an ultralow interlayer interaction of 0.056 mJ m-2, thus possessing a far lower friction coeff. compared with graphene, when acting as a lubricant. Moreover, it was also easy to exfoliate by shearing, due to the diminutive interlayer friction and eliminated commensurate stacking. The exfoliated no. of layers of less than three exceeded 80% (monolayer rate ≈ 40%), and no surfactant was applied to prevent further stacking.

Graphene oxide (GO) alters zero bandgap of graphene to achieve photoluminescence (PL), while the low quantum yield (generally: PLQY < 1%) seriously restricts its further development in practical applications. Here we employ two-step fluorination strategy to controllably modify GO, achieving island structure of arom. regions in continuous phase of fluorine regions. The fluorinated product (FGO) presents a high PLQY of 66%, far exceeding the largest value (21.2%) reported for modifications of GO. We systematically and meticulously investigate fluorine effect of FGO during whole PL evolution. In excitation process, the coexistence of fluorine and arom. regions in FGO is responsible for new electronic bandgap structure then multitudinous excited electrons produce, thus providing foundation for strong PL. In emission process, Raman measurements show that the weaker electron-phonon interactions in FGO result in slower nonradiative decay. It is attributed to that FGO possesses larger rigidity, as demonstrated by temp.-dependent fluorescence spectra, broadband dielec. measurements, d. functional theory calcns. and IR spectra. Interestingly, different types of fluorine-related groups in FGO play different roles. That is, unoriented CF2 and CF3 groups realize passivation of defects, and C-F bonds perpendicular to graphene plane contribute to weakening interlayer interactions, both greatly enhancing PL.

Controlling the functionalization of graphene is essential for many applications. Here, we probed the reactivity of monolayer and bilayer graphene samples with intentionally prepd. specific nos. of defects. Fluorination was used as a model reaction. We demonstrate that the reactivity of the single-layer graphene is not significantly affected by oxygen plasma-generated defects. On the other hand in the case of graphene bilayers, a decrease in the reactivity was obsd. for a small no. of new defects, while an increase in reactivity was found for a larger no. of defects. The long-term stability test of the fluorinated samples showed that minor changes in the sample occur during the first week after fluorination.

This paper reports the use of a fluorinating agent, diethylaminosulfur trifluoride (DAST), to effectively reduce graphene oxide (GO) thin films at a relatively low temp. (50 °C). XPS, Fourier transform IR spectroscopy, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction, and sheet resistance measurement were used to investigate the redn. process. The C/O at. ratio and sheet resistance of the GO films reduced by DAST were 9.24 and 398 Ω/.box. resp., which are comparable to the reduced GO films of similar thickness (6.5 μm) produced by hydrazine vapor. GO film redn. by DAST is advantageous in preserving the film intactness, owing to the mild reaction conditions involved. A small amt. of fluorine (3-4 at.%) was incorporated into rGO by DAST redn. which was confirmed by XPS and FTIR, which might influence the elec. properties of rGO or render it suitable for further functionalization. Further, our findings suggest that special attention should be paid to the steric hindrance of the hydroxyl groups in GO while adapting org. chem. methods for GO redn. and functionalization, which could alter reaction outcome significantly and could also be exploited for steric protection.

In this study, the scalable and one-step fabrication of single at.-layer transistors is demonstrated by the selective fluorination of graphene using a low-damage CF4 plasma treatment, where the generated F-radicals preferentially fluorinated the graphene at low temp. (<200 °C) while defect formation was suppressed by screening out the effect of ion damage. The chem. structure of the C-F bonds is well correlated with their optical and elec. properties in fluorinated graphene, as detd. by XPS, Raman spectroscopy, and optical and elec. characterizations. The elec. cond. of the resultant fluorinated graphene (F-graphene) was demonstrated to be in the range between 1.6 kΩ/sq and 1 MΩ/sq by adjusting the stoichiometric ratio of C/F in the range between 27.4 and 5.6, resp. Moreover, a unique heterojunction structure of semi-metal/semiconductor/insulator can be directly formed in a single layer of graphene using a one-step fluorination process by introducing a Au thin-film as a buffer layer. With this heterojunction structure, it would be possible to fabricate transistors in a single graphene film via a one-step fluorination process, in which pristine graphene, partial F-graphene, and highly F-graphene serve as the source/drain contacts, the channel, and the channel isolation in a transistor, resp. The demonstrated graphene transistor exhibits an on-off ratio above 10, which is 3-fold higher than that of devices made from pristine graphene. This efficient transistor fabrication method produces elec. heterojunctions of graphene over a large area and with selective patterning, providing the potential for the integration of electronics down to the single at.-layer scale.

The recent discovery of graphene has sparked much interest, thus far focused on the peculiar electronic structure of this material, in which charge carriers mimic massless relativistic particles. However, the phys. structure of graphene-a single layer of carbon atoms densely packed in a honeycomb crystal lattice-is also puzzling. On the one hand, graphene appears to be a strictly two-dimensional material, exhibiting such a high crystal quality that electrons can travel submicrometre distances without scattering. However, perfect two-dimensional crystals cannot exist in the free state, according to both theory and expt. This incompatibility can be avoided by arguing that all the graphene structures studied so far were an integral part of larger three-dimensional structures, either supported by a bulk substrate or embedded in a three-dimensional matrix. Here the authors report on individual graphene sheets freely suspended on a microfabricated scaffold in vacuum or air. These membranes are only one atom thick, yet they still display long-range cryst. order. However, the authors' studies by TEM also reveal that these suspended graphene sheets are not perfectly flat: they exhibit intrinsic microscopic roughening such that the surface normal varies by several degrees and out-of-plane deformations reach 1 nm. The atomically thin single-crystal membranes offer ample scope for fundamental research and new technologies, whereas the obsd. corrugations in the 3rd dimension may provide subtle reasons for the stability of two-dimensional crystals.

Black P (BP) is a desirable anode material for alkali metal ion storage owing to its high electronic/ionic cond. and theor. capacity. In-depth understanding of the redox reactions between BP and the alkali metal ions is key to reveal the potential and limitations of BP, and thus to guide the design of BP-based composites for high-performance alkali metal ion batteries. Comparative studies of the electrochem. reactions of Li+, Na+, and K+ with BP were performed. Ex situ x-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy combined with theor. calcn. reveal the lowest use of BP for K+ storage than for Na+ and Li+, which is ascribed to the highest formation energy and the lowest ion diffusion coeff. of the final potassiation product K3P, compared with Li3P and Na3P. As a result, restricting the formation of K3P by limiting the discharge voltage achieves a gravimetric capacity of 1300 mAh g-1 which retains at 600 mAh g-1 after 50 cycles at 0.25 A g-1.

Though graphitic carbons are com. available for various electrochem. processes, their performance is limited in terms of various electrochem. activities. Recent expts. on layered carbon materials, such as graphene, demonstrated an augmented performance of these systems in all electrochem. activities due to their unique electronic properties, enhanced surface area, structure and chem. stabilities. Moreover, flexibility in controlling electronic, as well as electrochem. activities by heteroatom doping brings further leverage in their practical use. Here, we study the electron transfer kinetics of fluorinated graphene derivs., known as fluorinated graphene oxide (FGO) and its reduced form, RFGO. Enhanced electron transfer kinetics (heterogeneous electron transfer (HET)) is obsd. from these fluorinated systems in comparison to their undoped systems such as graphene oxide (GO) and reduced GO. A detailed study has been conducted using std. redox probes and biomols. revealing the enhanced electro-catalytic activities of FGO and RFGO, and electron transfer rates are simulated theor. This study reveals that fluorine not only induces defects in graphitic lattice leading to an enhanced HET process but also can modify the electronic structure of graphene surface.

We studied the influence of salt on a com. available carbon black (Ketjenblack 600, KB) in carbonate solvents commonly applied in rechargeable batteries. Adopting the typically used salts: lithium hexa-fluorophosphate (LiPF6), lithium bis(trifluoromethane sulfonyl) imide (LiTFSI), as well as sodium hexafluorophosphate (NaPF6) dissolved in mixts. of ethylene carbonate and propylene carbonate, we investigated both the zeta potential and the flocculation kinetics of the KB particles as a function of salt concn. between 0.01 mM and 1.0 M. Clear evidence was found for the preferential adsorption of cations. In the absence of salt, KB was found to carry a neg. surface charge, but this gets neutralized by Li+ at very low concns. (∼1 mM), and by Na+ at intermediate concns. (∼30 mM). In the case of lithium ions, the increased adsorption at higher concn. led to a recovery of the colloidal stability around 3-30 mM, depending on the anion. At high concns. exceeding 30-100 mM, all salts cause flocculation of the KB particles, due to a redn. of the elec. double layer thickness. Since the charge neutralization of the KB by Na+ takes place in the same concn. regime, no re-entrant stability is found for Na+. These findings could have implications in formulation protocols for semi-solid flow batteries, or other systems where an intermediate stable regime could assist mixing and/or structure formation at small length scales.

Graphene-based nanomaterials have attracted great attention for energy storage application in supercapacitors and batteries, along with challenges and perspectives in the exciting field; however, the Li ion batteries with long cycling stability remain a major impediment. In order to enhance the Li+ ion adsorption, d. functional theory is employed to investigate the adsorption of Li+ ion with hydrogen-, fluorine-, chlorine- and bromine-terminated pristine sheet and the corresponding Stone-Thrower-Wales and divacancy defect-incorporated graphene sheet. The results reveal that fluorine termination enhances Li+ ion adsorption compared to H- and other halogen-terminated graphene sheets. On the other hand, Li+ ion adsorption energy is increased on introducing the fluorine termination in both pristine and defected graphene sheets, while Li+ ion adsorption is more in the divacancy-defected graphene. From the d. of states anal., the Fermi level shows 1.9 eV shift toward the valence band for fluorine termination in both pristine and defected graphene sheets. Fluorine termination is shown to have a significant variation in the valence band than the other halogen atoms, and hence, it offers efficient material energy conversion and storage.

The electrode-electrolyte interface has been a crit. concern since the birth of lithium(Li)-based batteries (lithium or Li+-ion batteries) that are operated with liq. electrolytes and in recent years to increase the operating voltages. The electrode-electrolyte interfacial behavior has also been in sharp focus with respect to intensively pursued solid-electrolyte-based (polymer- or ceramic-electrolyte) lithium and Li+-ion batteries. Understanding the relevant chem./electrochem. reactions, structural/compositional characteristics, and thermodn./kinetic behaviors at the electrode-electrolyte interface is of paramount importance for the development of strategies to enhance overall battery performances. Although the relevant research has been emphasized for many years, both a fundamental understanding of the interfacial phenomena and the practical strategies for enhancing the interfacial properties are still limited or vague. Due to the complexity involved in the interfacial behavior, the future research and development require collaborative efforts involving the disciplines of chem., physics, materials science, nanoscience/nanotechnol., as well as computational modeling/simulation. This review presents the key findings, recent progress, current status, and a bold perspective/vision for further understanding and manipulating the electrode-electrolyte interfaces in lithium and Li+-ion batteries. The information provided in this review is expected to benefit the current Li+-ion technologies and future-generation solid-state lithium and Li+-ion batteries that are based on polymer electrolytes or ceramic solid electrolytes.

We report on a comparative d. functional theory (DFT) study of ethylene carbonate (EC) decompn. on unlithiated, Li-covered, and fully-lithiated Sn surfaces as well as a pure Li surface. Results show that EC mol. does not dissoc. on unlithiated Sn modelled by the clean β-Sn(100) surface, but rather adsorbs intactly via dispersion interaction. However, EC mol. spontaneously dissocs. over Li-covered β-Sn(100), fully-lithiated Li17Sn4(001), and Li(100) surfaces. The dissocd. EC mol. (C2H4+CO3) is energetically much more favorable than the intact EC mol. on these surfaces. We find that the dissociative adsorption of EC mol. is stronger on Li/β-Sn(100) and Li17Sn4(001) than on Li(100) in spite of larger electron transfer in the last case. This result indicates that besides electron transfer, chem. compn. also plays an important role on dissocn. of EC mols. A detached CO-23 anion catches two Li atoms from the Li-rich surfaces and forms a Li2CO3 mol., which is the building block of a main component of the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer on Sn anodes according to the exptl. observations.

A review. Li-ion battery technol. has become very important in recent years as these batteries show great promise as power sources that can lead us to the elec. vehicle (EV) revolution. The development of new materials for Li-ion batteries is the focus of research in prominent groups in the field of materials science throughout the world. Li-ion batteries can be considered to be the most impressive success story of modern electrochem. in the last two decades. They power most of today's portable devices, and seem to overcome the psychol. barriers against the use of such high energy d. devices on a larger scale for more demanding applications, such as EV. Since this field is advancing rapidly and attracting an increasing no. of researchers, it is important to provide current and timely updates of this constantly changing technol. In this review, we describe the key aspects of Li-ion batteries: the basic science behind their operation, the most relevant components, anodes, cathodes, electrolyte solns., as well as important future directions for R&D of advanced Li-ion batteries for demanding use, such as EV and load-leveling applications.

The storage of elec. energy at high charge and discharge rate is an important technol. in today's society, and can enable hybrid and plug-in hybrid elec. vehicles and provide back-up for wind and solar energy. It is typically believed that in electrochem. systems very high power rates can only be achieved with supercapacitors, which trade high power for low energy d. as they only store energy by surface adsorption reactions of charged species on an electrode material. Batteries which obtain high energy d. by storing charge in the bulk of a material can also achieve ultrahigh discharge rates, comparable to those of supercapacitors. The authors realize this in LiFePO4 (ref. 6), a material with high lithium bulk mobility, by creating a fast ion-conducting surface phase through controlled off-stoichiometry. A rate capability equiv. to full battery discharge in 10-20 s can be achieved.

The recent development of lithium rechargeable batteries results from the use of carbon materials as lithium reservoir at the neg. electrode. Reversible intercalation, or insertion, of lithium into the carbon host lattice avoids the problem of lithium dendrite formation and provides large improvement in terms of cycleability and safety. This paper reviews, with 149 refs., the main achievements on performance and understanding of charge-discharge mechanisms, resulting from the tremendous activity devoted to these systems in the past few years. As a matter of fact. all carbon materials can be lithiated to a certain extent. However, the amt. of lithium reversibly incorporated in the carbon lattice (the reversible capacity), the faradaic losses during the first charge-discharge cycle (the irreversible capacity), the profile of the voltage curves during charging and discharging, all depend on the structure, the texture and heteroatom content of the carbon material. We successively examine the electrochem. behavior of the main families of materials, namely, natural and synthetic graphites, graphitizable carbons, low-temp. and non-graphitizing carbons, and doped carbons.

Graphene and related two-dimensional crystals and hybrid systems showcase several key properties that can address emerging energy needs, in particular for the ever growing market of portable and wearable energy conversion and storage devices. Graphene's flexibility, large surface area, and chemical stability, combined with its excellent electrical and thermal conductivity, make it promising as a catalyst in fuel and dye-sensitized solar cells. Chemically functionalized graphene can also improve storage and diffusion of ionic species and electric charge in batteries and supercapacitors. Two-dimensional crystals provide optoelectronic and photocatalytic properties complementing those of graphene, enabling the realization of ultrathin-film photovoltaic devices or systems for hydrogen production. Here, we review the use of graphene and related materials for energy conversion and storage, outlining the roadmap for future applications.

A review. The ever-increasing demands for energy and environmental concerns due to burning fossil fuels are the key drivers of today's R&D of innovative energy storage systems. This paper provides an overview of recent research progress in graphene-based materials as electrodes for electrochem. energy storage. Beginning with a brief description of the important properties of single-layer graphene, methods for the prepn. of graphene and its derivs. (graphene oxide and reduced graphene oxide) are summarized. Then, graphene-based electrode materials for electrochem. capacitors and lithium-ion batteries are reviewed. The use of graphene for improving the performance of lithium-sulfur and lithium-oxygen batteries is also presented. Future research trend in the development of high-power-d. and high-energy-d. electrochem. energy storage devices is analyzed.

Graphite is the most widely used anode material for lithium ion batteries (LIBs). However, the performance of graphite is limited by its slow charging rates. In this work, porous graphite was successfully prepd. by nickel-catalyzed gasification. The existence of the pores and channels in graphite particles can greatly increase the no. of sites for Li-ion intercalation-deintercalation in graphite lattice and reduce the Li-ion diffusion distance, which can greatly facilitate the rapid diffusion of lithium ions; meanwhile, the pores and channels can act as buffers for the vol. change of the graphite in charging-discharging processes. As a result, the prepd. graphite with pores and channels exhibits excellent cycling stability at high rate as anode materials for LIBs. The porous graphite offers better cycling performance than pristine graphite, retaining 81.4 % of its initial reversible capacity after 1500 cycles at 5 C rates. The effective synthesis strategy might open new avenues for the design of high-performance graphite materials. The porous graphite anode material is proposed in applications of high rate charging Li-ion batteries for elec. vehicles.

A challenge in the development of Li ion batteries is to simultaneously achieve high power and large energy capacity at fast charge and discharge rates for several minutes to seconds. N- or B-doped graphene can be used as a promising anode for high-power and high-energy Li ion batteries under high-rate charge and discharge conditions. The doped graphene shows a high reversible capacity of >1040 mA-h/g at a low rate of 50 mA/g. More importantly, it can be quickly charged and discharged in a short time of 1 h to several tens of seconds together with high-rate capability and excellent long-term cyclability. For example, a high capacity of ∼199 and 235 mA-h/g was obtained for the N-doped graphene and B-doped graphene at 25 A/g (∼30 s to full charge). Probably the unique 2-dimensional structure, disordered surface morphol., heteroat. defects, better electrode/electrolyte wettability, increased inter-sheet distance, improved elec. cond., and thermal stability of the doped graphene are beneficial to rapid surface Li+ absorption and ultrafast Li+ diffusion and electron transport. The doped materials are accordingly superior to pristine chem. derived graphene and other carbonaceous materials.

Creation of nanopores on graphene planar sheets is of great significance in promoting the kinetic diffusion of electrolyte and enhancing the utilization efficiency of graphene planar sheets. Herein, we developed a facile chem. vapor deposition strategy to prep. highly porous graphene with flake-like MgO as template and ferrocene as the carbon precursor. The graphene layers show a highly porous structure with small mesopores of 4-8 nm, large mesopores of 10-20 nm and addnl. macropores of 100-200 nm. These nanopores on graphene sheets provide numerous channels for fast ion transport perpendicular to the 2D basal plane, while the good powder cond. ensures an effective electron propagation within the 2D graphene plane. As a result, a specific capacitance of 303 F g-1, an areal capacitance up to 17.3 μF cm-2 and a nearly tenfold shorter time const. were achieved when compared with those of nonporous and stacked graphene electrodes. The method demonstrated herein would open up an opportunity to prep. porous graphene for a wide applications in energy storage, biosensors, nanoelectronics and catalysis.

A review. Heteroatom doped carbon materials represent one of the most prominent families of materials that are used in energy related applications, such as fuel cells, batteries, hydrogen storage or supercapacitors. While doping carbons with nitrogen atoms has experienced great progress throughout the past decades and yielded promising material concepts, also other doping candidates have gained the researchers' interest in the last few years. Boron is already relatively widely studied, and as its electronic situation is contrary to the one of nitrogen, codoping carbons with both heteroatoms can probably create synergistic effects. Sulfur and phosphorus have just recently entered the world of carbon synthesis, but already the first studies published prove their potential, esp. as electrocatalysts in the cathodic compartment of fuel cells. Due to their size and their electronegativity being lower than those of carbon, structural distortions and changes of the charge densities are induced in the carbon materials. This article is to give a state of the art update on the most recent developments concerning the advanced heteroatom doping of carbon that goes beyond nitrogen. Doped carbon materials and their applications in energy devices are discussed with respect to their boron-, sulfur- and phosphorus-doping.

The application of Li ion battery (LIB) in portable electronics and elec. vehicle has received tremendous attention, however, challenges remain in seeking suitable high-capacity anode materials with excellent rate performance and thus potentially to boost the energy/power d. Here the authors report an arc-discharge prodn. of high-quality F-modified graphene as anode for LIB with high-rate capability. As a result of F-modified, the acquired graphene exhibits high at. ratio of C/O, excellent elec. cond. and more crumpled and wrinkled surface. The in-situ formation of LiF nanoparticles during the 1st Li+ insertion process not only act as barriers to effectively prevent the agglomeration and re-stacking of graphene sheets but also enhance the interlayer spacing, thus providing enough void for rapid Li+ ion insertion/extn. These optimized features enable the resultant F-modified graphene delivers a high reversible capacity (783.2 mAh g-1 at 100 mA g-1), outstanding rate performance (298.5 mAh g-1 at 10 A g-1), and excellent cycling stability (> 91% capacity retention after 1000 cycles), providing great application prospect in high-energy-power LIB.

N and F co-doped graphene (NFG) with the N and F content ≤3.24 and 10.9 at.% resp. was prepd. through the hydrothermal reaction of triethylamine tri(hydrofluoride) [Et3N·3HF] and aq.-dispersed graphene oxide (GO) as the anode material for Li ion batteries (LIBs). The N and F co-doping in graphene increased the disorder and defects of the framework, enlarged the space of the interlayer, wrinkled the nanosheets with many open-edge sites, and thus facilitated Li ion diffusion through the electrode compared with sole-N or F doped graphene. XPS anal. of NFG demonstrated the presence of active pyridine and pyrrolic type N, and highly elec. conductive graphitic N and the semi-ionic C-F bond in the structure. The N and F doping content and the component types of N and F functional groups could be controlled by the hydrothermal temp. The NFG prepd. at 150° exhibited the best electrochem. performances when tested as the anode for LIBs, including the high coulombic efficiency in the 1st cycle (56.7%), superior reversible specific discharge capacity (1075 mA h g-1 at 100 mA g-1), excellent rate capabilities (305 mA h g-1 at 5 A g-1), and outstanding cycling stability (capacity retention of ∼95% at 5 A g-1 after 2000 cycles), which demonstrated that NFG was a promising candidate for anode materials of high-rate LIBs.

We report the synthesis and evidence of graphene fluoride, a 2D wide bandgap semiconductor derived from graphene. Graphene fluoride exhibits hexagonal cryst. order and strongly insulating behavior with resistance exceeding 10 GΩ at room temp. Electron transport in graphene fluoride is well described by variable range hopping in 2 dimensions due to the presence of localized states in the band gap. Graphene obtained through the redn. of graphene fluoride is highly conductive, exhibiting a resistivity of <100 kΩ at room temp. Our approach provides a pathway to reversibly engineer the band structure and cond. of graphene for electronic and optical applications.
